awd_titl_txt: Instrument Development for Ultrahigh-throughput 3D Chemical Imaging via Glow Discharge Optical Emission Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Gamez at Texas Tech University is developing an ultra-high throughput surface elemental mapping technique based on measuring the light emitted from a glow discharge. It is important to obtain spatial-resolution of chemical information to order to understand natural systems and improve the efficiency of manufacturing (that is to see where impurities might be). Current imaging techniques, however, present several challenges. On the one hand, many techniques require several hours to tens of hours to obtain a surface element map with high resolution. On the other hand, current higher sample throughput techniques may not be widely accessible.  Some high throughput techniques require the use of synchrotron radiation facilities which are relatively rare. Professor Gamez is working on a glow discharge optical spectroscopic technique that could potentially map element distribution >1000x faster than typical techniques. As such, imaging protocols currently  limited by analysis time restrictions may become routine diagnostic tools. This research impacts many scientific research fields, from materials to biological sciences. The project also offers training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate researchers with regard to instrument development, fundamental studies, and application development in plasma-based optical hyperspectral imaging and surface analysis. Professor Gamez works with a number of local programs to recruit next generation STEM students, in particular those from underrepresented minority groups.

Glow discharge optical emission spectroscopy (GDOES) has been recently shown to enable spatially resolved lateral information to be obtained from within the sputtering surface area by operating the GD in pulsed-power and at higher pressures. These modes of operation become are important as it is no longer required to raster pixel-by-pixel to obtain a hyperspectral data cube with the elemental distribution information.  This savings may translates into several orders of magnitude faster analysis times. The overall goal of this project is to develop an ultrahigh throughput-, 3D-, large area surface chemical imaging technique based on GDOES. The three objectives are to: 1) develop hyperspectral imaging systems and novel GD instrumentation to enable GD 3D chemical imaging, 2) study the underlying GD mechanisms through OES and laser scattering plasma diagnostics, and 3) develop applications in materials, biological and geological sciences enabled by GDOES 3D chemical imaging. In addition to the overall goals, this research may improve comprehension of GD scaling, enhance the characterization of trends in molecular OES under GD conditions, and enable of a variety of imaging protocols in different fields.

por.por_cntn:
It is critically important to obtain spatially resolved chemical information to understand natural systems and improve the efficiency of manufactured systems. Current imaging techniques, however, present several challenges. On the one hand, many techniques require several hours to tens of hours to obtain a surface elemental map with high enough pixel density. On the other hand, current higher sample throughput techniques may not be widely accessible, for example, requiring the use of synchrotron radiation facilities.

Here, we developed glow discharge optical emission spectroscopy (GDOES) to allow elemental mapping (EM) with several orders of magnitude faster throughput than typical techniques. Briefly, GDOES allows direct elemental analysis of solid surfaces via cathodic sputtering sampling followed by excitation of atomic/ionic species and light emission from within the plasma. Its advantages include that it allows depth profiling with high depth resolution (~nm) and multi-elemental quantitative analysis in a very fast manner (μm/min). We previously showed that GDOES allows obtaining spatially resolved lateral information from within the sputtering surface area by operating the GD in pulsed-power and at higher pressures. The importance of such mode of operation becomes clear when one realizes that, as opposed to typical techniques, one does not have to raster pixel-by-pixel to obtain the elemental distribution information, which translates into >1000x faster analysis times. As such, imaging protocols currently reserved for fundamental studies, due to analysis time restrictions, will be able to be translated to routine diagnostic analysis. This will have an impact in many fields, from materials to biological sciences.

This project allowed to enhance GDOES EM accessibility and throughput by coupling it to compressed sensing (CS) single pixel spectral imaging. This approach allows using highly-cost effective single pixel detectors, instead of expensive scientific cameras, to collect the EM information. Just as software processing allows compressing large image files, CS allows a similar compression during the data acquisition step which results in significantly faster analysis. In addition, geometric super resolution was achieved in a push-broom spectral imaging system (PBHSI) for GDOES EM. Typical imaging systems are limited by the physical pixel size on the detector. PBHSI, for example, relies on scanning the image across the detector one pixel detector length at a time. We overcame this limitation by shortening the step size, or sub-pixel shifting. While this resulted in the signal of several images being jumbled at the detector, we could then extract the sharper images through software processing.

The EM operating conditions are different from typical GDOES so this project also allowed to understand further the changes in plasma behaviour, which is important to know how to improve its performance. Thus, the newly developed geometric super resolution method was used to study the three dimensional distribution of excited atoms and molecules in the plasma. In addition, we designed and constructed a novel triple grating spectrograph (TGS) to permit mapping the plasma concentration of electrons, and their energy, as well as the temperature of the plasma gas. This new instrument was shown to yield the lowest detection limits of electron number density for laser scattering measurements of plasmas used for chemical analysis.

Furthermore, a sampling interface was developed which allowed analysis of samples mounted on microscope slides. This permitted showing the GDOES EM technique advantages applied to different types of samples, such as geological thin sections.

 This project produced several peer-reviewed publications, and several others under development. In addition, 20 student researchers, including undergraduates and graduates, were trained in elemental analysis, advanced spectroscopy, instrument development, plasma diagnostics, chemical imaging, and image processing. Their work was disseminated at local, national and international conferences, with one poster receiving an award. The project?s work was recognized in the form of the PI receiving the biennial Young Scientist Award in Plasma Spectrochemistry at the Winter Conf. in Plasma Spectrochemistry 2020. Also, this project allowed a middle-school outreach program, with the theme of light/matter interactions, to foster interest in science. Moreover, a community outreach program Chemistry ?magic? show was developed to nurture science interest among Title 1 primary school students and their families.
